commentBody: Great theme!  Easy and enjoyable.
Glad to have Will back (a day late on realizing this). Three seconds off my Wednesday best. Probably would have obliterated it if I hadn't had a sneezing fit while solving...

MEDAL or MEtAL seemed to work because for the not domestically inclined, DIY frequently ends at the TIY stage: “Tried It. Yikes.”

Or so I’ve heard.

I blinked and it was done.

:-)

Welcome back Will!

Also welcoming Will back.  2 notes:
(1) "VOLT" and "AMP"  do make a power couple, but only when they are together -- Volts ×  Amps = Watts, and watts are a unit of power...
(2) I don't quite get why XMAS is "Present day, in brief"...  Isn't today (Tuesday, Dec 31) more NYE than XMAS?
Shouldn't the clues for 7-Across and 5-Down in today's Mini be flipped? Or am I tripping?

Hi Wordplay editors and Emu-masters, I have a suggestion. I'd love for Mr's Fagliano & Shortz to write two guest columns, or one long one, about what it was like editing / not editing the puzzles this past year. We've had a full year of Fagliano's editing, and many of the commenters discerned aspects to the editing style they felt were unlike Shortz's. I'd like to hear from the editors about that. I'd like to read about what it was like to edit these puzzles, and I'd like to hear from Mr. Shortz about how he spent the year, and how his recovery progressed. Maybe both of them have written about it elsewhere, but I think Wordplay would be a perfect place for some extended commentary. T

here is a lot of affection for both editors here, and I think the last year has been full of good to great puzzles, and that the level, quality and creativity did not drop off at all this year. What does Shortz think about the job Fagliano did? What does Fagliano think he's learned over the course of the year?

How about it, boys?

Enjoyed the theme - but what amused me most was the clue for DIY.
“Simple home improvement projects”, LOL.

You identify the simple project.
You declare it to be DIY.
You buy some parts and they’re the wrong type of thingy.  You remove the broken thingy and find additional “simple” problems on display. Let’s not leave out the inevitable disagreement with the other DIYer in the household.
With any luck, the mess you make can still be salvaged by the person you eventually hire.
Hope springs eternal for 2025!

Thank you, Michael Lieberman, for a fun puzzle!  Welcome back, Will Shortz!

Happy New Year, everyone!  Good fortune and happy solving to all!

"You like studying electricity?"
"Currently, I'm amped up!"

("Watt do you mean?")
I’ve heard of an Iraqi and an Iranian, but never an Irani?

Shoutout to my mom for completing the crossword with me every day this year - mostly through (stressful) phone calls and (millions of) screenshots. Thank you to the crossword creators and NYT staff for creating such incredible puzzles to keep mother x daughter connected across the country. 

Let’s go, 2025!!!

New personal best for Tuesday! 
Favorite clue: Present day, in short. I completed it on crosses and it took a minute to click when I admired the puzzle. Thank you for the fun solve Michael Lieberman!

Great puzzle, by Lieberman and Shortz.  

I had a good flow going.   I can feel having to stop and think more for the puzzle to makes sense.  

Tomorrow is the seventh day of Christmas.  That whole 12 days of Christmas song is because Christmas season does last that long.
How did I miss yesterday’s return of Will Shortz? A banner day.  Wonderful to have him back and kudos to his fabulous team that filled in so well in his absence.

If you’re reading this, you’ve probably grown accustomed to the ~crosswordese~ of various French words, Japanese beer & dog breeds, and few-lettered avian names (looking at you, emu!). 

But ADIOS AMIGO, in the recent Friday puzzle and now today, is something I didn’t expect to see again so soon!

Adios Emugo (Am-emu?)!
Watching 48 down as I was doing the puzzle. 😊  (Dexter).  I wonder if I would have figured out the clue if I wasn't watching Netflix at the same time.

The best TWOsday one could ask for, smoothly constructed, with pop names that even I could get from the crosses.  The sweetest one of those was a SONG, and all of the TWOs were funny.  I especially appreciated that the puzzle didn't go ASKEW in service of the theme and had so many clever clues.  

Thank you so much, Michael Lieberman.  ADIOS AMIGO, and please make us another puzzle soon—IT'S UP TO YOU!

Shouldn’t the answer to 40A be plural? DOUBLE DIGIT(s)? All the other theme answers are plural, and this one is not. Or am I overthinking it?

Enjoyable puzzle, though, and I liked the theme.

To Bill in Philadelphia,

Didn’t want the year to slip away without responding to you.  

I stand by my comment. I’m entitled to my opinion, just as you’re entitled to yours, even when it’s wrong.
Since I can’t respond to emails I’ll just say here what a delight it’s been to read Sam Corbin’s Gameplay newsletters.

Great end to another great year of crossword solving. Just returned home from Maui for the holidays and was excited to see that Will is back. Thank you to Joel and the gang for stepping up this year in his absence. And congratulations to Michael on 25 published puzzles. That’s impressive! My kids are encouraging me to take a stab at constructing one, so my first New Year’s resolution is to submit at least one puzzle this year.
I’m shipping Lisa and Jafar as a spooky power couple.
Hmm..another contender for "King of Mambo"!

Nice puzzle and a fairly smooth solve. Just needed some down crosses for each of the theme answers to dawn on me. That just made for some nice 'oh, of course' moments. Very odd puzzle find today. A Sunday from December 7 (!), 1986 by Charlotte Shore with the title: "...Such sweet sorrow..." A couple of theme clues and answers: "Tune for author Hesse?" AUFWIEDERSEHENHERMANN "Remark from Mrs. Guinness?" TATASIRALEC And some other theme answers: SOLONGMARLON CIAORAMON HASTALAVISTAFRANCISCO Not sure I entirely grasp some of those. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/7/1986&g=22&d=A I'm done. Our feet are stained. ..

Short and sweet, though TIL MELD. Played gin rummy for years as a kid without knowing that term. (Apple still auto corrects gin to gun, sigh).
Happy New Year to all, starting with our Oz commenters and working West. Hogmonay celebrations already cancelled as the latest storm looms, London fireworks iffy too as the wind speeds are forecast to be 60-70mph. We’ll just have to stay in the pub and drink more. Cheers.

love the themed clues today! 

i also have been playing gin rummy for around 30 years and had never heard the term "meld" before and i'm wondering if we all learned by word of mouth--can't say i've ever actually read the rules 🤣
I hope I’m not the only one who channels their inner Edna Maude when exclaiming “No CAPES!” when the clue comes up…

Pair of socks. Ouch. 
Memories of pouting on present days past.

Wishing all a stoic 2025.

This is a tight theme.  Lovely theme answers, all of them, and for fun, I tried to come up with more.  It was no easy task.  The two that hit me were TWIN BILL, clued [BEAK, INVOICE], and DUPLICATE BRIDGE, clued [DENTURE, SPAN], but I don’t like them because “twin” and “duplicate” mean that the examples are exactly the same, and they’re not.  

Amazingly, tight as this theme is, Michael found answers that fit symmetrically.  Actually, all four theme answers have the same number of letters (11)!

Tight *and* symmetrical.  A pair of bravos on that, Michael!

I liked seeing a couple of echoes to recent puzzles – a down ARROW countering Sunday’s UP ARROWS, and ADIOS AMIGO, which appeared Friday.  I also liked seeing ABYSS smack dab at the bottom.  In addition, I loved seeing five palindromes, including a rare-in-crosswords five-letter one in TENET.

Michael, you have had 18 daily puzzles in the Times, and they have appeared every day of the week, except for Saturday.  Is “hit the cycle” one of your New Year’s resolutions?  

In any case, your lovely puzzle today ended the solving year for me on a sweet note.  Thank you so much for making this!

Super fast and fun.
It's been said before but it
[KODIAK,POLAR],
if you're once bitten by a tougher puzzle, don't let yourself be
[BASHFUL,MEEK].
It will get easier the more you solve!
A nice variety of entries with a fun theme,  just right for a Tuesday in my opinion.

As a electronics buff, you had me at 17A.
Every time, I mean every time I fill in LOA for Mauna ____ clue. I guess I'm just NUTS about the place.
Glad that Sam will see us through 2025!!

There's really a card game called WAR? Wow. 

I thought that was invented by Mad magazine in the '70s, for a joke about what Sherman really said: "Don't try to tell me what war is. Hell, I was playing that card game before you were born, soldier."

A lot of proper nouns I didn't know today, as well as never getting on the right wavelength for the big across solutions. So a bit of a slog for me.

DEXTER and a nod to Luther... these are two of my favorite......

Happy New Year to all.

A MELD, more often heard in Pinochle, is a run of some number of cards. Never heard it used in Gin Rummy but,,,, I dusted off my Super MENSA card and figured it out

Thank you Michael
Will Shortz edited today's puzzle! Welcome back!

Two-fer Twosday?

Too cool.

To toot my own tuba,
I tootally tuned in to
this two-rific, 
tubular tootsie-pop
of today’s twooly
trouble free trick.

👍 👍 
 
Toodles to 2024!

A nice Tuesday puzzle. But why use VOLT, AMP as the POWERCOUPLE? Neither of these is a unit of power. How about something like HYDRO, SOLAR? Simpler, and more correct to boot. 

Liked "Apple gadgets" for CORERS, and "Orange box" for CRATE. And, of course, "Present day, in brief" for XMAS.

Enjoyed the flashback from Friday, when ADIOSAMIGO was at 29D instead of today's 28D.

Strands thread.  No spoilers please until after the View All Replies button: 

Strands #303
“Resolutions”
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🟡

OK.  Forget what I said yesterday about not starting the thread.  Today was so good I had to jump in.   I even saved the spanner for last, which was well hidden.

To the gang here, and that includes, Deb, Caitlin, and Sam – you provide the perfect chaser to solving the puzzle, taking it from a solo to a group experience, where I become enmeshed in wit, humor, insight, reactions, and stories. What a gift!  Warm wishes to all of you for a sweet 2025, and may it be sparked with a surfeit of happy surprises!

The last time I saw an orange CRATE, it was 1957.  And I can't find an actual CORER (not the "slice and core" thing, I mean an actual hand-held gadget that allows the user to control the depth of the core being removed, as for baked apples.)

I had STONY, HALT, IRONED, SABERS--sp!-- and began 40A with DIGIT....so, some nice little misdirects.  Good thing these FriXion pens have erasers.  

Didn't we see this constructor recently?  ......
XMAS was last week, not present day. I don’t get it.

What a fun theme! 

I hope you all have a wonderful New Year!

Maybe I've been doing crosswords for too long; I didn't just know the Disney villain, but his parrot's name as well.
Michael, 25 puzzles!? Dude, that's awesome – congratulations!
Had to come to complain that XMAS was last week, to get the clue was talking about presents, rather than the present.
So happy to see Will's name on this puzzle.  Welcome back!

Absolutely delightful.  Cute and amusing and original.  Another theme I wish I'd thought of.  The exceptionally well-chosen themers are all different enough that each one brings its own special chuckle.  My favorite was DOUBLE DIGIT, but has PAIR OF SOCKS ever been clued more deliciously?  Kudos, Michael-- this is as good as a Tuesday puzzle gets.
Welcome Back Will❤️

I laughed out loud when I solved 17A. My first try was "resistance," but it was a letter short. However, I knew Ohm's Law was the key--and I always used the acronym PIE to remember it (P=IE: power (watts) = impedance (ohms) x electromotive force (volts)).

I was also amused by ADIOS AMIGO, in nearly the same position it was used a few days ago!

All in all, a fun Tuesday with very clever cluing.

As a lifelong card player, and especially fond of pinochle, rummy, and cribbage, I’ll chime in on “melding.” The word is the same as the German reflexive verb “sich melden,” “show oneself/itself” or “make an appearance.”

This is because merely having a particular card or combination of cards is not sufficient. The card(s) must be shown (melded) for all to see in order for the points (or, in rummy, rights) to be earned by the melder.

In each game there are different melds. Pinochle takes its name from the meld of the scandalous pairing of the Jack of Diamonds with the Queen of Spades (two one-eyed adulterers: binocular). In Cribbage, the point for the Jack of the turned-up suit (his nobs) along with all other points counted at the end of play are only pegged when the hand is laid out for all to see.

Rummy is of a different sort, but a melding game nonetheless. When the melds are laid out in front of a player, the player earns the right to unload cards on other melds. A player who hasn’t melded sits with a fistful of cards and is prevented from laying off certain cards. Gin rummy depends on a coup where only one hand is melded, sticking the others with their point totals all at once.

On a related note: I didn’t enjoy playing War as a child, because it made me car-sick even when played on the living room floor.

Just a shout-out to the NYT staff, to the 365 puzzle authors, and to the Comments corps, for helping me through 2024, my Anno Horribilis.
Please take care, stay healthy, alert and primed. I'll surely be needing my daily dose of diversion. If you hear primal screaming coming from somewhere, it's probably just ME---stuck on that last, pesky single letter that remains blank in my grid!
In other words, HAPPY NEW YEAR!
Doubletrouble. My pairofpuzzles got me on a twodaytuesday streak!

Fun puzzle for the end of 2024 which I found a little easier than yesterday’s. Thank you to the folks at NYT Puzzle Central. Thank you to Sam, Deb, and Caitlin for wonderful columns day after day. Happy to read that Will Shortz continues to make progress in his recovery. Today may be the end of our current streak (1,725) as we’re beginning our vacation to Antarctica and don’t know how good the Internet will be. Happy New Year to all!
So, Gods in his heaven and all's right with the world.

Delightful puzzle… I didn’t understand the DEXTER clue, but the crosses worked for me.  I started hoping it was DEXTER because of Dexter Gordon… got me to dust off the old albums and listen to the great saxophonist… thanks!

Word to the wise; DIY projects are often not so simple. Santa brought me a "smart" thermostat for XMAS. Line 1 of instructions: "This device requires a C, or common wire for power." Guess what my existing wiring did not have? That's right, a C wire. I had to order a special power adapter to make it work, but there was a very helpful online video to guide me through the process. Still, I found myself missing my dad, the electrical engineer, yet again.

I was so tickled with myself for remembering that a French king is rey. Obviously, we run across it somewhat frequently, but this was the first time I was able to confidently plunk it in on the first go. Yay, roi!

A little later as the puzzle revealed itself, I was slightly less tickled with myself to realize it was actually spelled rei. 😆

In the final analysis, at least the R was correct.  One out of three correct letters isn't too bad... A pair of errors at least fit the theme better than a trio...  😂

And who knows, maybe I can keep my French and Spanish kings straight now. 

In semi related news, back in August, some kind commenters out here gave me a trick to remember agora, which was one that I always knew I knew (Greek marketplace) but couldn't quite remember. Anyhow, sadly, it hasn't shown up since then. I just can't wait to plunk it in!! Pretty sure I'm going to get all five letters of that one right!
Cute and clever. Thanks.
I thought this was a little trickier than the usual Tuesday but nothing too crazy. The theme was fun
Yankee Doodle🎶 is now stuck in my head.

A fine finale for 2024. Thanks, Michael, for a fun, zingy puzzle!

Sam, since misery enjoys company, I commiserate with you over our metal over medal misstep! That was a bit sloppy of us, wasn't it? So often with puzzles I breeze through, I make a mistake such as this. Oh well, 2024 wasn't perfect either! Looking forward to making the best of 2025, and I hope everyone else is, too!
My first ever comment in this forum is to suggest a musical clue for this theme: [f,p] which would obviously solve to DYNAMICDUO.
I thought Mauna _ had to be LOA but it could only be KEA by the crosssings. Definitely a tricky clue for me.
Why is "Present day" XMAS on New Year's Eve?

Phew. Nice puzzle and I'm glad the King of Mambo issue has been addressed.

And crossing Jobs with the Apple Gadget was clever...
I may have filled 24A “Apple gadgets” last because of having blocked out the unpleasantness of the comments when the same word was the Wordle solution on Oct. 15.

Loved the little surprise Happy New Year’s message in today’s Mini! The crosswords, this column, and many of these crossword reflections continue to bring me a daily dose of joy. Thanks to all who make it happen!
Lovely puzzle today. I was stuck for a moment then suddenly the remaining three theme answers jumped out at me and I finished in a satisfying flurry. Happy new years and happy to see Mr Shortz back.

Late puzzle find - never seen one like this before. A Sunday from February 21, 1988 by Frances Hansen with the title: "Excuze my spelling." Eleven theme answers in that one and the only hint beyond the title was that the clues for the theme answers (which were straightforward) were capitalized. And... all of the theme answers were misspelled. Some examples: ADOLESENCE MAYONAISSE COMITTMENT ACCUMMULATE EMBARASSED Odd one. Here's the Xword Info link. https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=2/21/1988&g=25&d=A ...
This was a bad puzzle who counts up to three at new years everyone counts down from ten.
Happy New Year, Pani! And all the other lords and ladies of Bridgerton (and Crosslandia) as well.
Question! I’m new to the app and to doing the puzzle on my (i)phone. If you need to put a word (vs a letter) in a space, how is that done?

Finished this puzzle this morning. This evening, I’m working on a puzzle from the archive, 12/27/2019, and encounter a familiar clue: “Alternative to hasta la vista,” with an answer of ADIOSAMIGO! Felt like a glitch in the matrix.
HAPPY NEW YEAR, NYC! ❤️❤️❤️

@Sam Lyons bronze is an alloy. 

Pedants rejoice 😀

@Sam Lyons 

Btw, Sam.  I'm still thinking about renewing last years resolution to read the Shakespeare plays that I don't know well.  There aren't that many left.

For the record, this was as far as I got beyond the one we talked about.

Two Gentleman of Verona:  Much like Shrew and Ado it has many lines that read as serious but are openly staged and played for laughs.

Anthony and Cleopatra:  A body count of characters greater than Hamlet.  Some fine scenery-chewing speeches.  Overdrawn emphasis on strict and sober Rome vs decadent Egypt.  Anthony has an advisor named Eros . . . a big clue to his decline.  Did Cleo twice retreat her fleet from battle because she thought she could seduce Octavian as she had Caesar and Anthony?

Timon of Athens:  My edition's introduction says something to the effect of "rarely performed without customization".  The moral of the play is that you don't learn who your friends are until you really need them then get suicidal when they disappoint.

Richard II:  The usurpation by Bolingbroke who becomes the Henry IV of three following plays.  Another historical example of "I didn't actually say to kill him".
@Ιασων. And alloys are still metals, they just happen to be mixture not pure
@Alex it’s a day for presents (as in gifts)
@Alex Present day: day of exchanging presents.

@Alex
That one gets me every time. Anyway, Merry Christmas, etc.  ‘Tis the season.

@Alex 

It’s the sixth day of Xmas today.  So it counts.  Xmas doesn’t end until the Feast of the Three Kings on Jan 6,

@Red Carpet … yes and or, for some, Christmas ends on January 5th and, for others on the Feast of the Baptism of the Lord, and for still others, 40 days after Christmas, on Candlemas (February 2nd).  Maybe there are even more. But, at any rate, in the context of the clue, I do think the time for exchanging presents was meant, as previously mentioned.

@Jeanne 

In the Methodist church, new members pledge to support the congregation with their "prayers and presence."  One year, a teen-ager spoke after joining the church, and gave a very sweet speech, asking, "Where are these presents that they're talking about?"  She went on in this vein without ever realizing that she had mixed up the homophones.....

@Mean Old Lady 

Somebody’s going to come along and say that “presence” and “presents” are not pronounced alike…

@Mean Old Lady That’s hilarious!  Thanks for the laugh!

I was at a Catholic Mass when a young woman, probably in her twenties, read the word “gentiles” in a Bible verse incorrectly and told the entire congregation about the good news being proclaimed to the genitals.  She was totally unaware of her mistake.  The priest, who was listening with his eyes closed, made a barely perceptible grin while my husband and I gripped each other’s knees to keep from laughing out loud.

@BJ 

It’s a New Year’s countdown, starting from ten.
@BJ See the explanation above by Steve L. It took me a minute for the aha moment when it soved through crosses.

@Spelling Marauder

I'm so silly... You're right!
@john ezra ....Check link to Brain and Life Magazine within NYT 12/29 piece by Everdeen Mason for Will Shortz 1st person account of his recovery year.

@Cindy and @Michael --

Thanks for the links! That answers a lot of my questions about Will Shortz's recovery. I'd still lobby for Joel Fagliano to write a piece on his experience and for Shortz to do a guest column on WP about what it was like to work on puzzles this past year (the Everdeen Mason article said that Shortz still directed the Xword tournament this year, started picking puzzles for the NYT in May -- something I hadn't known -- and got back to creating puzzles for NPR's weekend edition in March). 

It appears that Shortz's two strokes affected mainly mobility, which must have been a great relief to him, since many strokes affect language centers in the brain. I'm sure it was a worry for all who knew him or enjoyed the benefits of his wordmeistership that the strokes might have diminished his super-logo-powers. Him being back as editor of the crossword answers those concerns, obviously, but there may be more to say about that. 

And a valedictory address from Joel Fagliano would be very welcome indeed!

Have a great new year!

@Cat Lady Margaret 

Remember there will be several intervening trips to the hardware store.  And who has the power in the couple?

@Cat Lady Margaret 
Yes, we snaked out the bathroom sink drain, only to find the pipe was so corroded, it had to be replaced. It took three trips to get the right sized part. That reminds me, I still have to return one of the non-fitting parts.

@Mike 

You look like you're wired. Were you LED on by a short connection?

@Mike 
Your puns add a spark to my mornings.
I wish I could come up with some phenOhmenal pun...

Can the online puzzle commentariat continue to generate positive energy over the returning editor,
or will Shortz irk it?
Phen*ohm*enal puns!

@Mike 
You are one of the best pun generators I have known.  You can take a word and transformer into an alternator different meaning with little or no resistance.  I try, but you run circuits around me.

@Patrick J.

Mike thrusts, Patrick ampere-ies!
Lesser-user alternative, maybe, but quite common among Americani.

@Red Carpet 

All true, but I hope you're not saying this is the reason for 54A.  That's is there because "present day" can mean "day of gifts".

"Present day" has been used in clues to signal REINDEER ("Package deliverers of the present day"), SAINTNICK ('Present day figure"), PERE NOEL ("...in Paris"), CHRISTMAS EVE )"Time before the present day?"), OPEN IT ("Present day demand?"), and of course XMAS (twice).

Note that none of these clues had a hyphen; a whole other set of clues of a similar nature give more options, including (irrelevant to the Dec. 25 theme, but to clarify another question in this column) "Present-day Persian" for IRANI.

So clearly not every "present-day" clue has to do with the man with the bag.
@Steve L And here I thought the puzzle was mistakenly run a week late. Nice!

@Steve L 
I was all ready to question XMAS too. Thanks for the clarification. Fun puzzle today!

@Steve L 

True.  But my brain was focused on the present as in the here-now - not as in gifts.
@Steve L Glad you explained that one. My first thought was someone goofed and published the puzzle on the wrong day.

@UE 
It wouldn't fit in the grid if it was plural, which is probably the only reason it wasn't. 

..........................................
.............................

@UE 

There’s one indicator of duality in every theme answer. In one case, it’s PAIR. In another, it’s TWO. In another, it’s COUPLE. In this one, it’s DOUBLE. 

The theme is common phrases with an element of duality. The plural ending isn’t necessary except to make the theme entry a normal phrase. You wouldn’t say “pair of sock”, so only “pair of socks” works. However, you could say “two-pointer” or “two-pointers”; same for “power couple(s)” and “double digits/double-digit”.  Either choice works; the constructor used the ones that were 11 letters. 

There’s no need for plural consistency. Just that the answers be recognizable phrases.
@Rrose Selavy What a lovely comment to stumble upon -- thank you so much!
Yesterday’s SHIP sunk deep, didn’t it?
@Times Rita do you have a suggestion for what we could use instead? One or two words that means "root for [x] and [y] as a romantic couple"?

@Kara 
'Relationship' is already one word, but apparently too long for the youth of today to waste time saying the whole thing. So I presume you actually meant you want one or two syllables to represent the concept?

My gut reaction is that the concept is so inane that there doesn't need to be a term for it, but regardless; how about 'Matchmake'? Or if two syllables is still too much, shorten it to 'Match'? 
Or how about 'Pair'? Or 'Couple'?

@Grumpy As a septuagenarian, may I say that I would not like to type "relationship" on my phone, and "Pair" isn't interesting enough. In any case, a slang abbreviation isn't really any good unless it annoys prior generations, is it?

(I started to say, "unless it annoys you old folks," but was afraid someone would take offense.)

@Kara

I vote for the word “casting”. To cast is already a verb that means to put someone in a role. I’m casting Lisa as Jafar’s love interest. She’s probably not thrilled.

@Justin 
I remember when Twilight was a huge thing, and fandom was split over whether Bella should choose the vampire or the werewolf. Teamsomebody hashtags were the means of conveying preferences. I don't know how that was resolved, and I don't care. But if people who do care want to have a slangy verb for that, knock yourself out.

@Grumpy 
Totally agree with you. Seems like the youth of today can't be bothered to utter anything longer than one or two syllables. We've always had shortened versions of words, e.g. "info," but this cohort has taken it to an whole other level. I find it abhorrent.

@Times Rita

Except that the terms "shipper" and "shipping" were apparently engendered on the X-Files Message Boards (of which I was a very enthusiastic participant) in the mid-90s, which would mean it's hardly The Youth Of Today. Thirty years ago is a generation ago.

And the choice of a short, succinct word or syllable to use as a nickname or slang for some oft-repeated concept is hardly new. It's not laziness, it's just linguistic human nature.

Also, the associated slang fandom terms "Darkside Intellishippers" and "Completely Irrational NoRomo Argumentation" are hardly brief, 'lazy' terms. (although of course we did acronymize the latter to "CINA").

I think if you look back to the 1920s, 1930s 1940s, etc etc etc etc you will find numerous one-syllable nicknames, abbreviations and acronyms for all sorts of things. It's not really a "new millennium" thing at all.

All I recognize about gin rummy is... The name itself. Maybe the game is unknown in Poland? There is no entry in Polish for it on Wikipedia, at least. Poland has some card games of its own, the strangest of them probably being "dupa biskupa" ("bishops [impolite word for one's behind]"): https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dupa_biskupa

@Andrzej 
It was considered a suitable card game for kids, at least in my Methodist house where gambling was forbidden. As I recall, I think it was 7 cards per player, the aim being to get rid of them first by matching groups; 3 of a kind or runs of 3 or more in the same suite. A fun game.

@Andrzej 
Having posted below I’ve just read @David Connell’s much better explanation of rummy rules and the Meld connection.

@Steven D 

I immediately pictured (and heard) Ms Mode. What a great character.

Administrative note: Tomorrow, I'll be posting my Favorite Clues of 2024 list...







Et tu, emu.

“best clues of 2025!”
“no, the awards are done in 2025 for the year preceding!”
“well, the clue is wrong about the year! it should say 2024!”
….

@Eric Hougland Yes, tough. It was deliberate mischief to title this one Resolutions on New Year's Eve. Only funny after the solve. First I tried looking for words like promise or pledge or challenge. Nope. Then for the typical subjects of such pledges: diet, weight loss, fitness, exercise, patience, understanding, attitude. Nope. Do-overs? Nope. Cringe? Nope. Some of you may be interested in the hoo-hah over Hanukkah's spelling in the Strands puzzle from Sunday. There's a long discussion on Janis Ian's facebook page, and an article on Forward. https://forward.com/.../a-strands-shanda-nyt-game.../

@Linda Jo Thanks for the link to the Forward article but for some reason it did not resolve for me so I did some digging: https://forward.com/fast-forward/685561/a-strands-shanda-nyt-game-misspells-hanukkah-in-festival-of-lights-themed-puzzle/ As I commented on Sunday, since the English spellings are transliterations there are a variety of acceptable versions but apparently the one with the original double N is least preferable. Regarding today's Strands solve I went through much the same process as you did until I saw S-O-L-V-I-N-G which was accepted for a hint. So I spent a lot of time looking for puzzle related New Year's resolutions with absolutely no luck. I then saw and selected E-N-D-I-N-G and the light bulb went off. Like Eric I've been a bit ambivalent about the game lately but, unlike him, I thought today's had a multiple layers of interesting possibilities.

@Steve - Slight correction: The I in PIE is current, measured in amperes. 

If you want to calculate power using resistance/impedance, you need to use P = I^2R, or P = E^2/R.

@Andrzej 
I meant to point out that your complaint the other day about [Big name in pest control] for ORKIN lead you to say, “what next, big name in manhole covers?” I thought it was a funny comment and after a bit of a rabbit-hole I discovered there’s a lot there. First, California has officially changed the name to the more gender-neutral, “maintenance cover.” There is a big history of their manufacture in India (Crescent Foundry is the biggest international supplier). A big U.S. name in manhole-covers is Neenah, which has a crossword-friendly number of vowels and has appeared twice in the NYT xwords (to be truthful clued as [City on Lake Winnebago].

@Sara O'Bannon 

KEA has been an answer 154 times total, and the specific clue [Mauna ___] was used 51 of those times.   KEA means "white" in Hawaiian, so if that's in the clue, it's KEA.

LOA, which means "long" in Hawaiian, has appeared 277 times, with the specific clue [Mauna ___] used 70 times.  

Both words have been clued [Mauna ___ Observatory], so that wouldn't help.

LOA most likely appears a little more often because the L is more useful than the K.

Pre-Shortz, [Mauna ___] could mean either, but KEA was almost always clued as a New Zealand parrot.  (But not always.)  LOA was almost always clued as the volcano, except a few times when it was clued as [Seat of Wayne Co., Utah], a 500-person place in a 2500-person county.  

I'd rather take my chances with the two volcanoes.

@Sara O'Bannon - This is often referred to as the KEALOA conundrum. 

You always know the A, but have to have at least one cross to get the others.
